phonegame
Class MoveableGameItem

java.lang.Object
  phonegame.GameItem
      phonegame.MoveableGameItem
Direct Known Subclasses:
GamePlayer
public abstract class MoveableGameItem
extends GameItem

Class MoveableGameItem represents a moveable actor in the game. MoveableGameItem is an abstract class. Create subclasses to make your MoveableGameItems.
The game engine does collision detection for MoveableGameItems. This is very time consuming, so make sure you only extend this class when the items are really moving!

Version:
2.0, October 11, 2005, 2.1, April 24, 2006, 3.0, November 17, 2006
Author:
Tim Prijn, Richard Kettelerij & Paul Bergervoet

Method Detail

bounce

public void bounce(boolean horizontal,
                   int pos)
Acting on a collision: bounce Move up to the wall you bounce against and reverse speed! You get the parameters from the collisionOccurred-call.

Parameters:
horizontal - boolean indicating if the collision is horizontal or vertical
pos - the collision position (xpos when collision is horizontal, ypos when vertical)

collisionOccured

public void collisionOccured(GameItem collidedItem)
This method is triggered when an collision between a MoveableGameItem (i.e. the player) and some other gameitem (i.e. a moveable enemy or a static wall) occurs.

NOTE:
Just the collision is detected, there is no direction or collision position. Therefore you can't bounce properly.

NOTE 2:
JCollisions between items are detected always, that means that invisible items can also have collisions.

Parameters:
collidedItem - the item that collided with this gameitem. The collidedItem parameter may be any GameItem: a non-moving item, a MoveableGameItem or the GamePlayer.

collisionOccured

public void collisionOccured(int tilePattern,
                             boolean horizontal,
                             int position)
This method is triggered when an collision between a MoveableGameItem (i.e. the player) and a tile (a block in the environment map) or row/column of tiles occurs. Please note that only MoveableGameItems can receive this type of events.

The tilePattern parameter tells you what tile types were hit in one time. In the bit pattern bit n (counting from the back) is switched on if a tile of type n has been hit. So if the tilePattern is 9 (binary: 1001), tile types 4 and 1 have been hit. Use the bitwise operators on ints to test.

NOTE:
In a single move many tile collisions can occur. Therefore you can receive several calls of this method on just one move. Just use the standard handing methods mentioned below to handle this event. If you want to jump at such a collision, set a Timer for the next turn, and jump then.

Parameters:
tilePattern - bit pattern indicating the tile types you have run into.
horizontal - a boolean indicating if the collision was horizontal.
position - the position of the collision: x when horizontal, y when vertical You pass these two parameters on when using bounce(horizontal, position) or moveUpto(horizontal, position).
See Also:
undoMove(), bounce(boolean, int), moveUpto(boolean, int).

getDirection

public int getDirection()
Gets the current direction in degrees.
Note: You can get small errors because of rounding. Also you may get the value -60, when you had set the value originally to 300! So watch it when you make tests like 'if (getDirection() == nnn )' !

Returns:
integer, direction in degrees

friction in pixels, as a double.

getYSpeed

public double getYSpeed()
Gets the speed in vertical (y) direction. A positive y-speed means that the object is moving down.

Returns:
y-speed in pixels, as a double.

public boolean hasCollisionDetection()
Ask if this MoveableGameItem is receiving collision events.

Returns:
boolean, true if the engine must detect collisions

jumpToStartPosition

public void jumpToStartPosition()
Resets the gameitem to its original starting position.
No collision detection!

movesLeft

public final boolean movesLeft()
Find out if item moves to the left. Utility method for collision detection.

Returns:
true if item is moving left, false if moving right, or not moving!

movesUp

public final boolean movesUp()
Find out if item moves up.

Returns:
true if item is moving up, false if moving down, or not moving!

moveTowardsAPoint

public void moveTowardsAPoint(int otherXPosition,
                              int otherYPosition)
The item moves towards a defined point with the current speed.

Parameters:
otherXPosition - X position of the point
otherYPosition - Y position of the point

moveUpto

public void moveUpto(boolean horizontal,
                     int pos)
Acting on a collision: move as far as you can The speed will not be changed. If you want to stop at the collision, you will have to set the speed to 0 yourself. You get the parameters from the collisionOccurred-call.

Parameters:
horizontal - boolean indicating if the collision is horizontal or vertical
pos - the collision position (xpos when collision is horizontal, ypos when vertical)

outsideWorld

public void outsideWorld()
This method is executed every time the gameitem moves outside the world. (as defined in the minX, minY, maxX and maxY properties of the GameEngine)
By default, nothing is done. If you want to take action when a GameItem moves outside the world, then you must override this method. For example, you can remove a bullet that has not hit anything and just flies away.

reverseHorizontalDirection

public final void reverseHorizontalDirection()
Reverses the horizontal direction of the items movement.

reverseVerticalDirection

public final void reverseVerticalDirection()
Reverses the vertical direction of the items movement.

setCollisionDetection

public void setCollisionDetection(boolean cd)
Turn collision detection on/off for this MoveableGameItem.
Note: By default, collision detection is turned on. Turning collision detection off speeds up the game.

Parameters:
cd - a boolean, true means on, of course!

setDirection

public void setDirection(int degrees)
Sets the direction of motion. Value is in degrees: 0 is to the right, degrees run counterclockwise, so 90 is up, etc. You can enter values smaller than 0 or greater than 360: 370 degrees = 10 degrees etc.

Parameters:
degrees - value usually between 0 and 360

setDirectionRadians

public void setDirectionRadians(double radian)
Sets the direction of motion. Value is in degrees: 0 is to the right, radians run counterclockwise, so pi/2 is up, etc.

Parameters:
radian - value usually between 0 and 2*pi

setDirectionSpeed

public void setDirectionSpeed(int degrees,
                              double speed)
Set the direction and the speed in which the item needs to move.

Parameters:
degrees - degrees Degrees value between 0 and 360
speed - The speed in pixels per cycle

setFriction

public void setFriction(double fpfriction)
This method sets the friction of the movement. The number you enter is the part of the speed the Item loses in every cycle of the game loop.
If you want a GameItem to slow down gradually, use numbers like 0.05, just greater than zero. This causes the GameItem to lose 5 per cent of it's speed every cycle.

Parameters:
fpfriction - double, the firction of the movement.

setPosition

public void setPosition(int x,
                        int y)
Sets the position of the item inside the game.
There will be no collision detection when an Item's position is set in this way.

Overrides:
setPosition in class GameItem
Parameters:
x - the horizontal position
y - the vertical position

setSpeed

public void setSpeed(double speed)
Set the speed of the object. Speed is measured in pixels per cycle.
Setting the speed does not change the direction. If at startup no direction is set, the Item will move to the right.
Normally you will enter an integer number, the number of pixels an Item will move per cycle.
You can also enter the speed of an item as a double value. In this way you can slowly change the speed of an Item, like from 6.0,to 5.9, 5.8 etc. Changing speed with integer values will often result in quick changes.)

Parameters:
speed - double, the speed in pixels per cycle. You may also enter an integer value.

setXSpeed

public void setXSpeed(double xspeed)
Sets the speed in horizontal (x) direction, with a double value. The vertical speed will not change. A positive x-speed means that the object is moving right.
Use this method only if you want to do special calculations on speed, that only affect one direction, like falling

Parameters:
xspeed - the horizontal speed in pixels, as a double.

setYSpeed

public void setYSpeed(double yspeed)
Sets the speed in vertical (y) direction, with a double value. The horizontal speed will not change. A positive y-speed means that the object is moving down.
Use this method only if you want to do special calculations on speed, that only affect one direction, like falling

Parameters:
yspeed - the vertical speed in pixels, as a double.

startMoving

public void startMoving()
Start moving this item.

stopMoving

public void stopMoving()
Stop moving this item.

undoMove

public void undoMove()
Undo last move. Typically used after a tile collision has happened
